00037 //
00038 // mIrc color codes
00039 //
00040 
00041 #define KVI_WHITE 0
00042 #define KVI_BLACK 1
00043 #define KVI_DARKBLUE 2
00044 #define KVI_DARKGREEN 3
00045 #define KVI_RED 4
00046 #define KVI_DARKRED 5
00047 #define KVI_DARKVIOLET 6
00048 #define KVI_ORANGE 7
00049 #define KVI_YELLOW 8
00050 #define KVI_LIGHTGREEN 9
00051 #define KVI_BLUEMARINE 10
00052 #define KVI_LIGHTBLUE 11
00053 #define KVI_BLUE 12
00054 #define KVI_LIGHTVIOLET 13
00055 #define KVI_DARKGRAY 14
00056 #define KVI_LIGHTGRAY 15
00057 
00058 #define KVI_MIRCCOLOR_MAX_FOREGROUND 15
00059 #define KVI_MIRCCOLOR_MAX_BACKGROUND 15
00060 
00061 //
00062 // Non-standard color codes for KviIrcView
00063 //
00064 #define KVI_TRANSPARENT 100
00065 #define KVI_NOCHANGE 101
00066 //
00067 // Internal control codes for KviIrcView
00068 //
00069 // (Totally artificial and internal to KviIrcView)
00070 #define KVI_TEXT_ESCAPE 0x04
00071 #define KVI_TEXT_UNESCAPE 0x05
00072 #define KVI_TEXT_UNICON 0x06
00073 //#define KVI_TEXT_EMOTICON 0x07
00074 
00075 // ASCII Stuff: the following defines are meant to be escape sequences
00076 //              that can go thru an IRC connection
00077 
00078 // The following table is a 30-minute analysis of the escape characters commonly used over the IRC protocol...
00079 // created when looking for a good placement for the CRYPT escape char in KVirc.
00080 // I guess that the best chars to be used were FS,GS,RS,US,DC1,DC2,DC3,DC4...they have the "less defined"
00081 // meaning as ASCII control chars.
00082 // mmmh... :) 
00083 
00084 // ASCII                              IRC Meaning
00085 // 000 NUL Null                       (Cannot be assigned)
00086 // 001 SOH Start of heading           ( CTCP Escape: only beginning of the message )
00087 // 002 STX Start of text              ( Bold text )
00088 // 003 ETX End of text                ( Color text escape sequence )
00089 // 004 EOT End of transmission        ( Assigned internally (escape) )
00090 // 005 ENQ Enquiry (WRU: Who are you) ( Assigned internally (unescape) )
00091 // 006 ACK Acknowledge                (Not so good, but can be used as last resource)
00092 // 007 BEL Bell                       ( Recognized as bell by terminals and IRCII ) (Used also by some IRC servers)
00093 // 008 BS  Backspace                  (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00094 // 009 HT  Horizontal tabulation      (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00095 // 010 LF  Line feed                  (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00096 // 011 VT  Vertical tabulation        (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00097 // 012 FF  Form feed                  (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00098 // 013 CR  Carriage return            (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00099 // 014 SO  Shift out                  (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00100 // 015 SI  Shift in                   ( Resets Bold,Color,Underline and Reverse ) (Conflicting with terminal control)
00101 // 016 DLE Data link escape           (Decent, can be assigned)
00102 // 017 DC1 Device control 1           (Good to be assigned)
00103 // 018 DC2 Device control 2           (Good to be assigned)
00104 // 019 DC3 Device control 3           (Good to be assigned)
00105 // 020 DC4 Device control 4           (Good to be assigned)
00106 // 021 NAK Negative acknowledge       (Not so good, but could be used as last resource)
00107 // 022 SYN Synchronous idle           ( Reverse text )
00108 // 023 ETB End of transmission block  (Decent, can be assigned)
00109 // 024 CAN Cancel                     (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00110 // 025 EM  End of medium              (Decent, can be assigned)
00111 // 026 SUB Substitute                 (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00112 // 027 ESC Escape                     (Should not be assigned: terminal control)
00113 // 028 FS  File separator             (Excellent, should be used as first candidate)
00114 // 029 GS  Group separator            ( ICONS Escape: beginning of a word )
00115 // 030 RS  Record separator           ( CRYPT Escape: only beginning of the message )
00116 // 031 US  Unit separator             ( Underline text )
00117 
00118 
00119 //
00120 // mIrc control codes
00121 //
00122 
00123 //31 (0001 1111) US (Unit separator)
00124 #define KVI_TEXT_UNDERLINE 0x1f
00125 //2  (0000 0010) STX (Start of text)
00126 #define KVI_TEXT_BOLD 0x02
00127 //15 (0000 1111) SI (Shift in)
00128 #define KVI_TEXT_RESET 0x0f
00129 //22 (0001 0110) SYN (Synchronous idle)
00130 #define KVI_TEXT_REVERSE 0x16
00131 //3  (0000 0011) ETX (End of text)
00132 #define KVI_TEXT_COLOR 0x03
00133 
00134 //
00135 // Irc control codes
00136 //
00137 //1 (0000 0001) SOH (Start of heading)
00138 #define KVI_TEXT_CTCP 0x01
00139 
00140 //
00141 // KVirc added control codes
00142 //
00143 //30 (0001 1110) RS (Record separator)
00144 #define KVI_TEXT_CRYPTESCAPE 0x1e
00145 //29 (0001 1101) GS (Group separator)
00146 #define KVI_TEXT_ICON 0x1d
00147

00149         extern KVILIB_API const char * getColorBytes(const char *data_ptr,unsigned char *byte_1,unsigned char *byte_2);
00150         extern KVILIB_API const kvi_wchar_t * getColorBytesW(const kvi_wchar_t *data_ptr,unsigned char *byte_1,unsigned char *byte_2);
00151         extern KVILIB_API unsigned int getUnicodeColorBytes(const QString &szData,unsigned int charIdx,unsigned char *byte_1,unsigned char *byte_2);
00152         inline const QChar * getUnicodeColorBytes(const QChar *pData,unsigned char *byte_1,unsigned char *byte_2)
00153                 { return (QChar *)getColorBytesW((const kvi_wchar_t *)pData,byte_1,byte_2); }
00154 
00155 #endif
